prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The molecular outflows are expected to be quite broad, ~500km/s, and the OH 119um line is a doublet with components separated by ~550km/s. We place the two 1.875GHz basebands next to each other to ensure continuous frequency coverage. We tune the upper baseband (baseband 4) to ensure that we will cover the blueshifted absorption from both line components, as well as any redshifted emission.
We aim to model the absorption profiles in ~150km/s channels. As such, we configure the correlator to cover the maximum possible bandwidth, and request spectral averaging by a factor of 16x to lower the data rate. The resulting spectral resolution, ~5km/s, is low enough to allow flexibility in later spectral averaging.

From our Cycle 0 observations (see Figure 1), we know SPT0418-47 is extended on scales of <~4", and that accurate lens models can be constructed from data with resolution as low as 0.9". In order to better constrain the outflow geometry, we request 0.6" observations, which will yield an image comparable to the bottom row of Figure 1. This resolution is intermediate between configurations C36-1 and C36-2. Given the expected array configuration schedule, SPT0418-47 will be observable at this resolution during nighttime hours more favorable to high frequency projects.

Extensive local observations of molecular outflows in OH indicate that the lines are typically broad, >~500km/s. As we desire to resolve the outflow geometry over >=3 consecuitve velocity bins, we use a bandwidth for sensitivity of 150km/s.
As opposed to studies of emission lines, the relevant quantity for absoprtion line sensitivity calculations is not the peak line brightness, but rather the necessary contrast with the continuum. Extensive observations of OH outflows in local galaxies indicate that we need ~5% contrast with the continuum in order to detect the outflowing gas at >=4sigma/beam.
The expected rest-frame 119um continuum of SPT0418-47 is 133mJy. From our Cycle 0 observations (see Figure 1), we know that the continuum emission will be extended over ~5 synthesized beams at 0.7" resolution. If the outflow has the same size as the continuum, this yields a necessary sensitivity of 1.2mJy per 150km/s bin. As we are observing an absorption line, the line absorption cannot be larger than 6.5 synthesized beams; smaller covering fractions will only increase the significance of our detections.

The expected rest-frame 119um continuum of SPT0345-47 is 167mJy. From our Cycle 0 observations (see Figure 1), we know SPT2311-54 is extended on scales of <~2.5", and that accurate lens models can be constructed from data with resolution as low as 0.5". In order to better constrain the outflow geometry, we request 0.3" observations, which will yield an image comparable to the bottom row of Figure 1. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Above stellar masses of log(M*/Msun)~11, the abundance of galaxies drops exponentially, even out to z~4. These galaxies host little ongoing star formation, and appear to have been quickly and efficiently "quenched," but the process(es) by which this quenching occurs are poorly understood. Theoretical models invoke feedback from AGN and/or star formation to disrupt, expel, or heat the gas supply and prevent further star formation. Recent observations and circumstantial evidence suggests that the bulk of star formation in the earliest quiescent galaxies took place in dusty, star-forming galaxies (DSFGs).
We propose to test models of feedback and the evolutionary connection between DSFGs and quiescent galaxies by spatially and spectrally resolving massive molecular outflows in six z~4.5 galaxies. Our observations will constrain the outflow geometry, mass loss rates, and feedback mechanism, allowing us to determine whether quenching is likely due to gas depletion or gas removal. These galaxies span a factor of 5x in star formation rate (SFR) and 20x in SFR surface density, giving a large dynamic range to constrain outflow scaling relations and extend local work to high-z.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.01238.S - PI C. de Breuck - An [OI] 63um Survey of Lensed Dusty Star-Forming Galaxies from the SPT Survey 2015.1.01485.S - PI D. Marrone - The Dynamics and Structure of Dusty Starbursts in the First 1.5 Gyr

Marrone - Imaging the Brightest Starbursts in the Universe 2012.1.00844.S - PI A. Weiss - CO redshifts of SPT Sources 2013.1.01231.S - PI D. Marrone - The Fine Structure of an Extreme, Lensed Starburst Galaxy at z=5.7
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
